title: req.url not correct for mounted routers
Support Requests directly from trusted proxy
body:
When returning the protocol used handle the case where the trusted proxy has made a request to a express directly.  When this occurs use the encrypted state on the underlying connection.

This happens with Amazon's ELBs with auto-scaling groups.  The ELB will ping and healthcheck endpoint on the node server to verify its health.  In this case there is no X-Forwarded-Proto header since the request originates directly from the ELB.

title: Support Requests directly from trusted proxy
body:
When returning the protocol used handle the case where the trusted proxy has made a request to a express directly.  When this occurs use the encrypted state on the underlying connection.

This happens with Amazon's ELBs with auto-scaling groups.  The ELB will ping and healthcheck endpoint on the node server to verify its health.  In this case there is no X-Forwarded-Proto header since the request originates directly from the ELB.

title: Error: Can't set headers after they are sent
body:
i have very simple app

``` js
var express = require('express')
var app = express()

app.get('/', function (req, res) {
  res.redirect( "some static path" );
})

app.listen(3000)
```

Got an error on big amount of requests

```
Error: Can't set headers after they are sent.
    at ServerResponse.OutgoingMessage.setHeader (http.js:691:11)
    at ServerResponse.res.setHeader (node_modules/express/node_modules/connect/lib/patch.js:130:22)
    at ServerResponse.res.set.res.header (node_modules/express/lib/response.js:568:10)
    at ServerResponse.res.location (express/lib/response.js:698:8)
    at ServerResponse.res.redirect (node_modules/express/lib/response.js:739:8)
    at app.js:5:8
```

Reproduced on big amount of concurrent requests.
Cannot reproduce  behind nginx.

title: Deprecate res.send(obj) json overload
body: This is an idea for removing the `res.send(obj)` signature and it's other similar signatures that will `JSON.stringify` the value and send it as JSON. In my opinion there is no reason you cannot just type `res.json` instead. Deprecating and removing this overload will mean people do not have to make sure their variable to `res.send` is a string to get HTML output.

title: Memory Leak with EventSource Stream
body:
I experience a memory leak with my express.js app when connecting a bigger number of _EventSource_ clients through  `text/event-stream` to the endpoint. While running the express server I log every second the _RSS_ and _Heap_.

The problem is after disconnecting all clients from the stream the _RSS_ and _Heap Used_ is not decreasing, even after manually calling the GC via `global.gc();` & `expose-gc`.

Can you give me any pointer how to find out why it's not getting cleared?

title: Make automatic HEAD -> GET configurable
body: The automatic conversion of `HEAD` requests to `GET` requests when there is no HEAD method in the route should be configurable (i.e. turn it on or off).

title: Make automatic OPTIONS responses configurable
body: The automatic OPTIONS responses should be configurable (i.e. turn it on or off).

title: Deprecate app.all('/*', fn)
body: This is an idea to deprecate and display a message when someone adds the route `.all('/*', fn)` (part of the preparation for https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/2173). The `*` at the end syntax is going away, and this specific case with `.all` is a prime thing to start yelling at people about now in 4.x since it makes no sense. I can't imagine a reason they wouldn't want `.use(fn)`, except for mis-understanding.

title: docs: add expressjs.kr(expressjs.com in Korean)
body:
I have completed initial translation of expressjs.com in Korean and now you can access via expressjs.kr 

I believe it will help many Korean developers access express easier.

For that reason, I’d like to include the path within readme file so that Korean developers who visit express repository will get to know this news.

title: I have completed initial translation of expressjs.com in Korean

Hi, all!
I have completed initial translation of expressjs.com in Korean and now you can access via expressjs.kr 

I believe it will help many Korean developers access express easier.

For that reason, I’d like to include the path within readme file so that Korean developers who visit express repository will get to know this news.

If this gets reflected in readme, Korean developers can access Korean-translated Express Official site by selecting [Kor, repo] next to Website and Documentation of express repository.

url: http://expressjs.kr
repository: https://github.com/Hanul/expressjs.kr

title: Method for bailing out of a router and returning to the previous middleware level
body:
Per conversation with @dougwilson on IRC, it would be very useful to have an equivalent for `next('route')`, but at the router level.  Calling it would cause a router to skip all remaining middleware and routes on that router.

This would allow for conditional execution of middleware, such as session handling and session related middleware only being evoked for users with an existing session cookie.

`next('router')` could work, but that might be too close of terms.

title: req.accepts doesn't play well with content type containing dots
body:
I just encountered this behavior:

``` coffeescript
console.log req.headers['accept'] is 'vnd.apiblueprint.parseresult.raw+yaml'
# true

console.log req.accepts 'vnd.apiblueprint.parseresult.raw+yaml'
# false
```

...while following works nicely:

``` coffeescript
console.log req.headers['accept'] is 'application/hal+json'
# true

console.log req.accepts 'application/hal+json'
# application/hal+json
```

I suspect that `req.accepts` doesn't play well with dots in custom content types. I tried the same thing in separate code snippet using only `accepts`, but that worked O_o

``` coffeescript
accepts = require 'accepts'
accept = accepts
    headers:
        'Accept': 'vnd.apiblueprint.parseresult.raw+yaml'
console.log accept.types 'vnd.apiblueprint.parseresult.raw+yaml'
```

``` shell
$ npm install accepts
$ coffee test.coffee
vnd.apiblueprint.parseresult.raw+yaml
```

I don't understand it. From my POW it seems to be an express' issue.

title: Mime types not dealing with m4a
body:
I am severing media content through my node/express service, the audio plays on all devices except apple. this is associated with the m4a file format. while I have place the proper solution in the mime.types file "audio/x-m4a   m4a" this does not work. When I use Apache ( with the correct mime.types) its does play on apple.
is this a bug / known issue with express and mime.types ?

title: How do I use res.send without setting charset?
body:
I need [these lines](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/8ba3f39b33042f59d50ef5b5fb87109d3f3a2a26/lib/response.js#L142:L144) to be optional. There's no way to avoid adding of charset to content type while using `response.send` currently.

Use case: Some content types are defined exclusively for one particular encoding. They have specific `charset` already by definition and there's no need to add it explicitely.

Appending `charset` seems harmless, but we build an API on Express.js and we don't want to _confuse_ our users by appending `charset` - they could think also other charsets could apply, which is not true and we don't want to encourage them even trying to use other charsets.

([more on topic of charsets within content types](http://lucumr.pocoo.org/2013/7/19/application-mimetypes-and-encodings/))

title: Release 5.0

labels.name: top priority
labels.description: Issues which the TC deem our current highest priorities for the project

body:
This is a tracking issue for release 5.0.

**_5.0.0-beta.1 published on npm_**

I am trying to give better visibility for upcoming changes and so am trying out making a PR for a release here, pulling from the official next release branch into 4.x. This allows for the current pending changes to be easily visible.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

I'm also leaving this PR unlocked so people can make comments/etc. and we'll see how it goes :) If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase (they will occur frequently has 4.x progresses).

The goal of Express 5 is to be API tweaks & the removal of all code from the Express repository, moving into components in the pillarjs project (https://github.com/pillarjs), providing at least basic support for promise-returning handlers and complete HTTP/2 functionality. Express 5 would become a "view into pillarjs" and would be an arrangement of these components.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add support for Promises in all handlers #2259 (though `router@2.0.0-alpha.1`)
- [ ] Add support for Promises in `app.param` (though `router@2.0.0-beta.2`)
- [x] Bring back `app.router` which is just generally useful for directly calling to the router
  - [ ] Make sure 3.x-style `app.use(app.router)` does not explode
- [ ] ~Fix views to resolve paths async #2653~
- [x] Make `query parser` option default to `'simple'` #3361
- [x] Make `bodyParser.urlencoded` default to `'simple'` (though `body-parser@2.0.0-beta.1`)
- [x] Make `req.host` actually return the host #2179
- [x] Make `req.query` a getter instead of added by middleware #2215
- [x] Make `res.render` always async callback, to hide sync view engines #2668
- [ ] ~Make `res.render` use the default engine even when an extension was found #2708~
- [ ] ~Make `res.sendFile` use the `"etag"` application setting #2294~
- [ ] Make `res.status` throw on invalid argument type #2795 #2797 #3111 #3137 #3143
- [ ] ~Make `express.static` use the `"etag"` application setting #2317~
- [x] New path matching syntax #2057 #2173 #4321 (though `router@2.0.0-beta.1`)
- [ ] ~Provide separate locals and options to view engine #2648~
- [x] Remove Express 3.x middleware error stubs #3217
- [x] Use `mime-types` instead of `mime`
- [x] Use `path-is-absolute` module for absolute path detection #2620 

List of deprecated things removed:
- [x] Leading `:` in `name` for `app.param(name, fn)`
- [x] `app.del`
- [x] `app.param(fn)`
- [x] `req.acceptsCharset`
- [x] `req.acceptsEncoding`
- [x] `req.acceptsLanguage`
- [x] `res.json(obj, status)`
- [x] `res.json(status, obj)` #2939
- [x] `res.jsonp(obj, status)`
- [x] `res.jsonp(status, obj)` #2940
- [x] `req.param()`
- [x] `res.redirect(url, status)` #2941
- [x] `res.send(body, status)`
- [x] `res.send(status)`
- [x] `res.send(status, body)` #2942
- [x] `res.sendfile`
- [x] `res.vary()` (i.e. no arguments) #2943

List of things to refactor (still provided by `express`):
- [ ] ~Better `res.cookie` and general cookie reading/setting (new `keygrip` and `cookies` modules; new `req.cookies` or such)~
- [ ] ~Move prototype properties to own repo #2432~
- [x] Move `Router` to it's own repo #2411

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:

``` bash
$ npm install expressjs/express#5.0
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: Release 4.7
body:
This is a tracking issue for release 4.7.

I am trying to give better visibility for upcoming changes and so am trying out making a PR for a release here, pulling from the official next release branch into master. This allows for the current pending changes to be easily visible.

**Please keep feature requests in their own issues**

I'm also leaving this PR unlocked so people can make comments/etc. and we'll see how it goes :) If you want to make a comment on a particular change, please make the comment in the "Files changed" tab so comments are not lost during a rebase.

List of changes for release:
- [x] Add Korean documentation #2242 #2244
- [x] Deprecate `res.send(status, body)` format #2227
- [x] Fix errors/hangs sending 500/404 if request had body https://github.com/expressjs/finalhandler/commit/00633b4186ca4d7f6ca91d5c8c04db7bddd8ec24
- [x] Fix `req.protocol` for proxy-direct connections #2252
- [x] Make `req.query` parsing configurable #2215

**Testing this release**

If you want to try out this release, you can install it with the following command:

``` bash
$ npm install visionmedia/express#4.7
```

You can also directly reference it in your `package.json`:

```
"dependencies": {
  "express": "visionmedia/express#4.7"
}
```

Owners/collaborators: please do not merge this PR :)

title: route Conflict
body:
I define this follow routes:

``` javascript
app.get('/api/tag/:id', getTag);
app.get('/api/tag/random', randomGetTag);
```

I use curl to test

```
curl localhost:8014/api/tag/random
```

that will only invoke `/api/tag/:id` 
so the `/api/tag/random` not work

title: retrieving params from mount path
app.mountpath incorrectly set when path not specified
body:
It seems that commit https://github.com/visionmedia/express/commit/997a558a73eb49d7f3b99ceec82c4c88bd3424a0 modified checking for arguments to `app.use`, setting `mount_path` and `mount_app` respectively. The code reads as if these resolved values should be used once they're set, however [line 171](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/8ba3f39b33042f59d50ef5b5fb87109d3f3a2a26/lib/application.js#L171) sets the mounted app's `mountpath` to the original `path` argument, which in some cases is the mounted app itself, creating a circular reference. The line appears to have been intended to be:

``` javascript
mount_app.mountpath = mount_path;
```

title: regex for router does not properly sanitize escaped paths
body:
To reproduce:

Generate app `myapp`:

```
$ express myapp && cd myapp/
```

Add route with named parameter defined with regex in `app.js`:

```
app.get('/:id([^\\.\/]+)', function(req, res) {
     console.log(req.params.id);
});
```

Expected behavior: `req.params.id` should never match `/^\/.+/`

Navigate to `http://localhost:3000/%2Fhello`

Observe `/hello` is logged as the value of `req.params.id`.

**If the value of `req.params.id` is escaped when it's passed through to the handler function, that escaped value should be constrained by the regex in the router.**

I'm not really sure what's going on, but when using cookie-session or client-sessions as middleware under express 4.5.1, I'm getting this error from my API endpoints:

title: Route handlers cannot have 4 args - error, req, res, next
Deprecate res.send(status, body) format
body:
This is a discussion regarding the possibility of deprecating `res.send(status, body)` and other methods (`json`, `jsonp` to name some) that do the same thing, where there is an optional first status argument.

Specifically, deprecating the optional `status` as a first argument thing.

/cc @defunctzombie

title: Fixed a bug when sending status code with a number.
Replace the "buffer-crc32" with "jhash"
body:
jhash will create shorter sum result and the performance is better.
It don't have to waste cpu to encoding a string into a buffer before calculating the hash.

Here's a simple benchmark's source code:
https://github.com/ysmood/nobone/blob/5e36ea738a57c69dce839eb2e595a4be2a73737d/benchmark/crc_vs_jhash.coffee

Here's the project home:
https://github.com/ysmood/jhash

As we can see, jhash is about 1.5x faster than crc32.
Their results of collision test are nearly the same.

```
Performance Test
crc buffer   x 5,903 ops/sec ±0.52% (100 runs sampled)
crc str      x 54,045 ops/sec ±6.67% (83 runs sampled)
jhash buffer x 9,756 ops/sec ±0.67% (101 runs sampled)
jhash str    x 72,056 ops/sec ±0.36% (94 runs sampled)
Collision Test
***** jhash *****
 5 samples: 3481292839,1601668515,957061576,1031084327,1000054056
      time: 10.001s
collisions: 0.0018788163457017504% (4/212900)
***** crc32 *****
 5 samples: 3494480258,2736329845,2815219153,3510180228,2016919691
      time: 10.003s
collisions: 0.0027945971122544933% (6/214700)
```

title: Allow router.use to take several handlers
body:
I often find myself doing something like the following

```
router.use('/users', handler1);
router.use('/users', handler2);
router.use('/users', handler3);
```

It would be handy if I could do the following instead

```
router.use('/users', handler1, handler2, handler3);
```

You can already do this for verbs on routes, e.g:

```
router.route('/users')
  .get(handler1, handler2, handler3)
```

If you are ok with this I'm happy to do a Pull Request myself.

title: Contributors
body:
Added some more people, lots of companies have investment so I don't think anyone should be singled out. Ultimately it's not a whole lot different than regular contrib anyway, same rules apply, ~2+ people should sign off on pull-requests and everyone can collab on bigger changes in branches or issues before merging.

Roman / Douglas / Jonathan have been doing the bulk of the work, and a good job releasing 4.x etc, so just for the sake of having some kind of order it's probably worth having them call the shots. Just throwing it out there so no one is surprised by all the new people haha.

Alternatively maybe it would be good to have one main representative per company. I don't know, you guys can figure that stuff out haha ;)

I'm still around for feedback etc too, just won't be actively reading issues or contributing.

¯(°_o)/¯

title: express.static serving wrong content type for css
`router.params` inconsistency between v4.1.1 and v4.3.2.
body:
Hi there,

I had a poke around and don't believe I saw this precise issue. There's some similar discussion in [issue 2151](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/issues/2151) but it focuses on `app.params`. Apologies if this is a duplicate regardless.

I have the following code which fails when upgrading from 4.1.1 to 4.3.2:

``` coffee

# -- Create router --

router = express.Router()

# -- Define params --

_(['placeId', 'clientId', 'userId', 'fluidId', 'issueId', 'contactId', 'fieldId']).each (paramName) ->
  router.param paramName, (req, res, next, value) ->
    req.params[paramName] = _.parseInt value
    next()

# -- Routes setup --

# ... define routes here using above params ...
```

When upgrading to 4.3.2 the params are not being converted to integers. For now my solution will be to roll back until I can understand what updates are required.

Also, while I've got this code in the eyes of the experts, is this the cleanest way to force parameters to integers?

Thanks for your time and fantastic product.

body:

he says it may not be totally backwards compatible, so we'll see what we can do

a really good view engine is https://github.com/ericf/express3-handlebars, but the one express includes should be able to use most templating languages

title: remove .get() and .set() functions for settings
body: and just do `app.viewEngine=` and stuff instead

title: remove/opt-out of `qs` module
body: looking through `qs`'s issues, it seems like there isn't even a consensus on how nested query string parsing should be. we should either remove it, opt out of it, or create semantics everyone could agree on and redo the `qs` module

title: Change double quotes to single quotes on line 503
remove acceptance tests
body: kind of noisy imo. most of the tests should be integrated into express's tests somehow. we should just move them into a `expressjs/examples` repo or something.

title: Add semicolons to JS code sample
Add bodyParser back to express 4.x
body: We have removed all the middlewares from being bundled with express (which is awesome, i.m.o), but left one: `static`. I think we really should bundle `bodyParser` again, because I think parsing bodies is probably even more common than serving static files and many people really have no idea how to read the body from `IncomingMessage` objects (aka `req`) in Node.js core for whatever reason.

title: docs: cleanup readme, update package description
body: Just keeping the docs a bit more inline with our styles and generally sane. :)

title: tests: fix deprecation error in router test
tests: make router test less noisy
Pass route array through to pathRegexp()
body:
Currently it's possible to do:

``` javascript
app.get(['/foo', '/bar'], ...);
```

or:

``` javascript
router.get(['/foo', '/bar'], ...);
```

but not:

``` javascript
app.use(['/foo', '/bar'], ...);
```

or:

``` javascript
router.use(['/foo', '/bar'], ...);
```

I started to write a PR for this but it's conflicting with the work currently being done on implementing request path retrieval.

title: Route params handler conflict
body:
We've recently updated a Express 3.x application to 4.x. I noticed the following error:

Given the following two routes:

```
app.get("/:someVar", fn)
app.post("/:someOtherVar", fn)
```

These two will compile to the same regular expression. Then, add two params handlers:

```
app.param(":someVar", function(req,res,next){ 
    next(new Error("Validation failed."));
});
app.param(":someOtherVar", fn)
```

You'd expect that a GET to /foo will fail and a POST to /foo will succeed. This is the case under Express 3.x but not under Express 4.x. The POST will also always fail.

Given two (or more) routes which compile to the same regular expression, the first one's middleware will be executed while matching. Even if the route params have different names.

A complete barebones express app can be found in [this gist](https://gist.github.com/Spekpannenkoek/bca9cf72e8205e424d54). It includes three example routes and a couple of tests. Try running them under Express 3 and Express 4. Notice that under 4, one of the unit tests fails.

title: what does `res.pipe` mean in the online express guide ?
body:
If `res` is the usual name for the http ServerResponse, then it's not possible to pipe from it.
Only `req.pipe(mywritable)` or `myreadable.pipe(res)` mean something ?!?

title: app.use(path,router) vs app.get(path,router) produces entirely different behavior
Update CORS example.
body:
According to the CORS spec, the POST method is a [simple method](http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/#simple-method) and does not need to be listed as part of the Access-Control-Allow-Methods response header. See number 9 on http://www.w3.org/TR/cors/#resource-preflight-requests 

> If a method is a simple method it does not need to be listed, but this is not prohibited.

This means the line:

``` javascript
res.set('Access-Control-Allow-Methods', 'GET, POST');
```

is completely irrelevant for the example.

This PR updates the example with an HTTP method that actually raises an error in case it's not listed as part of the CORS response headers.

title: Default err.status to 500 when less than 400.
body: @dougwilson let me know what your thoughts are on this.  It seems reasonable to me to treat this as a defect but the choice is yours and I'll respect your judgement.  Thanks!

title: err.status should default < 400 to 500.
body: Currently `next({status: 204})` creates a response with a `204` status code and `Content-*` headers.  If `next(err)` is meant solely for error responses, then anything less than a 400 `statusCode` should default to a reasonable `statusCode`.

title: Include DTrace probes
body:
It would be interesting to include a DTrace provider and some probes to express, in a similar way as it is already implemented in other frameworks such as [resitfy](https://github.com/mcavage/node-restify/search?q=dtrace):
- 'route-start': // server_name, route_name, id, method, url, headers (json)
- 'handler-start': // server_name, route_name, handler_name, id
- 'handler-done': // server_name, route_name, handler_name, id
- 'route-done': // server_name, route_name, id, statusCode, headers (json)

Express users could take advantage of these probes in DTrace-enabled operating systems  (OSX, Solaris, SmartOS, Oracle Linux, BSD...).

Are you open to contributions in this line?

title: Param missing in put/delete
Mistaken treatment of the route "/"
body:
Hey guys,

I noticed the following strange behavior and guess it is a bug, but I'm not quite sure. I apologize in case it ain't one.

I wondered, that the following code caused to match ALL ROUTES : 

``` javascript
app.use('/', index());
```

But this workaround helped me to avoid this unintended routing:

``` javascript
app.get(/\/$/, index());
```

Anyway, I found the piece of code, which was causing this bug, in express / lib / router / index.js (line 399):

``` javascript
 // strip trailing slash
  if ('/' == route[route.length - 1]) {
    route = route.slice(0, -1);
  }
```

so I tried to add one more condition (like `&& route !== '/'` or `&& route.length > 1'`) to prevent the shortening of `"/"`. This worked, but had the unfortunate side effect that the matching CSS file couldn't be loaded anymore (because this file was somehow also using the route `"/"`.

Doesn't anyone have an explanation for this?

BTW: My method `index( )` ist just returning a simple function, this couldn't be the reason for this behavior.

Regards,
Marius

title: "Failed to decode param" exception on params like  'abc%'
body:
Layer/SendStream runs into an exception getting written to the console when using code like `app.get("/:term", function(req,res) { res.json({}); }` paired with `app.param("term", function(req, res, next, term) { next(); }` and then asking for a route like `http://localhost/word%`. In terms of URI encoding this is rightfully an error, but it seems to generate an exception in a part of express that does not let one write code to deal with this exception.

(ran across this because % is a wildcard in MySQL/MariaDB, with an API styled as /:apikey/:resource/:searchterm, and someone passing straight up sql wildcards in the search term)

title: documentation typo issue
body: ![n-missing](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7904262/3311993/ad69d8fe-f6cb-11e3-94e4-ffbf0ecf3885.jpg)

title: res.send behaves strangely when provided two numbers
body:
Currently, if you call res.send with two numbers as the arguments, the first number essentially is ignored and the second is turned into an http status code.

For example `res.send(200, 1)` does not send an http status 200 response with a body containing 1, but instead sends an http status 1 response where the body is that status code.

This appears to be a result of trying to support the `res.send(body, status)` format for backwards compatibility.

title: Error: vhost server required
several callbacks in app.param()
body:
I think for the sake of consistency (and there is a use case in which I actually need the feature), app.param() should behave as the other app.VERB() methods (i.e allowing you to chain callbacks that individually augment the functionality applied to a rest call)

So far we can write: `app.get('/some/route', callback1, callback2, ..., callbackN)`. It is counterintuitive that the same cannot be done for param: `app.param('param', callback1, callback2, ..., callbackN)` will only call the first callback, then upon hitting `next()` it will move on to process the route.

What do you think?

title: Update view.js
body: can update add define path on function View.

title: req.host should be req.hostname
body:
Currently in express, `req.host` returns the _hostname_ instead of the host (i.e. it strips the port, if present). This should be renamed to `req.hostname` in the next major and `req.host` added that is the actual host and not the hostname.

/cc @dantman

title: Question about express middleware
Fixed: debug displaying values prematurely in router
Inherit parent local settings
body:
This is quite useful when you set script or style locations in the parent app, and in the child app you use it during render, like this:

``` jade
each style in styles
  link(rel='stylesheet', href=style)
```

If there is already a best practice for achieving this functionality, please tell me!

title: Update path regexp functionality
body:
- Old asterisk functionality is obsolete
- Adds the repeated parameters mentioned in visionmedia/express#2134

This will break backward compatibility

title: `res.format` order
`req.accepted` still in Documentation
body: [Documentation](http://expressjs.com/4x/api.html#res.format) still mentions `req.accepted`, although in [4.0](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/wiki/Migrating-from-3.x-to-4.x#reqaccepted) it is now `req.accepts()`. `req.accepted` is undefined.

title: app.param doesn't work for POST requests
Docs incorrect about JSON
body:
The docs say, about res.json:  "This method is identical to res.send() when an object or array is passed, however it may be used for explicit JSON conversion of non-objects (null, undefined, etc), though these are technically not valid JSON."

Non-objects are valid JSON.  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19569221/did-the-publication-of-ecma-404-affect-the-validity-of-json-texts-such-as-2-or

Non-objects are not valid application/json documents according to RFC-4627.  (Same source.)

But RFC-4627 is being replaced by RFC-7159, which does allow non-objects.  http://stackoverflow.com/questions/18419428/what-is-the-minimum-valid-json/22361229

title: CORS issue. The OPTIONS methods request has a body.
body:
The OPTIONS response has a body. The comma separated string of the allowed methods. This breaks an response at Android  less 3 version. 
https://github.com/visionmedia/express/blob/master/lib/router/index.js#L147

title: Use path.join instead of string concat
body: I just got bitten by this trying to run an express app on Windows. `path.join` allows us to be platform agnostic, so let's use it.

title: Fix console.log reference to port 4000
body: A small spelling error in reference to the multipart form example. It looks like the server is listening on port 4000, while the console.log states that "Express started on port 3000". Instead it should read "Express started on port 4000".

title: Using Multiple routers?
App crashing if no route is set
body:
Hello everyone,

I've noticed a weird behaviour with the latest version of Express (4.x). When I request a running express application that has no route set, the server crashes.
## Test case

``` javascript
var express = require('express');
var app = express();
app.listen(3000);
```

Then GET `http://localhost:3000`

```
/Users/joseph/Documents/Developement/cozycloud/dev-env/americano/node_modules/express/lib/application.js:125
  this._router.handle(req, res, function(err) {
               ^
TypeError: Cannot call method 'handle' of undefined
    at Function.app.handle (/Users/joseph/Documents/Developement/cozycloud/dev-env/americano/node_modules/express/lib/application.js:125:16)
    at Server.app (/Users/joseph/Documents/Developement/cozycloud/dev-env/americano/node_modules/express/lib/express.js:28:9)
    at Server.EventEmitter.emit (events.js:98:17)
    at HTTPParser.parser.onIncoming (http.js:2108:12)
    at HTTPParser.parserOnHeadersComplete [as onHeadersComplete] (http.js:121:23)
    at Socket.socket.ondata (http.js:1966:22)
    at TCP.onread (net.js:527:27)
```

I looked at the code and quickly figured why this crashed, but I had no idea on how you would like to see that fixed, and I don't even know if you actually consider this as a bug (no route webapp? eh).

This use case appeared in the tests of our framework based on Express. We test our route creation function so we first want to have get a '404 not found' error before setting the route and see that the routes have been actually loaded. This is where it goes wrong :)

title: how to test a router?
Optional parameters not marked as optional
body:
I use PhpStorm with nodejs and express development and it keeps highlighting me lots of code claiming I should pass more arguments to some functions. The most annoying case in express is app.use().

According to JSDoc (http://usejsdoc.org/tags-param.html), optional argument names should be places in [], so in case of app.use() it should be:
- @param {Function|Server} [fn]

instead of:
- @param {Function|Server} fn

title: PostgreSQL Date Issue
body: Dates are being returned as timestamp with timezone E.G My database has 1985-09-13 (type: Date) but when queried it returns Fri Sep 13 1985 00:00:00 GMT+0000 (UTC). Prior to this, i had, process.env.TZ = 'America/Barbados'; which produced Thu Sep 12 1985 20:00:00 GMT-0400 (AST). Based on this Express is capable of altering the dates it seems.

title: 404 & 500 Error pages
Allow routes on verbs under route, or provide parent params to nested routers
body:
Related to #2113.

I'm attempting to set up an endpoint that lists all users associated with a particular entity.  The entityId is important when fetching the list of users, but is abstracted in the route binding itself.

``` javascript
    app.route('/entity/:entityId/users')
      .get(userController.list)
      .get('/:userId', userController.get)
      .post('/:userId', userController.add)
      .delete('/:userId', userController.delete)
      .all('*', utils.responseFormatter);
```

This doesn't work because you can't do nested routes on the verbs.  Express expects a function as the first param.

So instead I tried:

``` javascript
    app.use('/entity/:entityId/users', express.Router()
      .get(userController.list)
      .get('/:userId', userController.get)
      .post('/:userId', userController.add)
      .delete('/:userId', userController.delete)
      .all('*', utils.responseFormatter));
```

This doesn't work because you can't access the `:entityId` param on the base route from anything bound on the router.  I'm left with not being able to use `app.route` or `express.Router` at all and have to just duplicate the full route everywhere:

``` javascript
    app
      .get('/entity/:entityId/users/', userController.list)
      .get('/entity/:entityId/users/:userId', userController.get)
      .post('/entity/:entityId/users/:userId', userController.add)
      .delete('/entity/:entityId/users/:userId', userController.delete)
      .all('/entity/:entityId/users/*', utils.responseFormatter);
```

Allowing for one or both of these methods of routing would be quite handy!
